translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Bīja

analyzed: o pa vayha ttheḥ a padāna  padumuttara buddhassa
translated: The Elder Opavayha’s Birth Story🔽“I gave a thoroughbred horse
to Padumuttara, the Buddha;
After dedicating it to the Sambuddha,
I went back to my own home.
The one named Devala,
the Teacher’s chief disciple;
The heir of the excellent Dhamma,
came to me.
The Fortunate One, with his burden laid down,
said a thoroughbred horse is not suitable;
Knowing my intention,
the one with vision consented.
After having had the horse, swift as the wind,
the Sindhava, a swift vehicle, valued,
I gave it to Padumuttara, the Buddha,
to be forgiven.
Whatever womb I was conceived in,
whether divine or human;
The horse to be forgiven, swift as the wind,
my mind is made up.🔽For those who obtain the higher ordination,
their gain is well-gained;🔽If there is a Buddha in the world,
I would serve him again.
Twenty-eight times I was a king,
very powerful;
Conquering the four directions,
I was the lord of the Rose-Apple Island.
This is my last birth,
the last birth is now turning.
I have attained the unshakable state,
having abandoned victory and defeat.
In the four-fold twenty-five thousand,
you are a Khattiya of great splendour;
Endowed with the seven treasures,
a powerful Universal Monarch.
The four analytical insights,

original: kataṁ buddhassa sāsanaṁ”.🔽Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā opavayho thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: katam buddhassa sāsana  ittham sudam āyasmai opavayhaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”🔽Thus the venerable Opavayha the Elder recited these verses.
The Story of Opavayha the Elder, the Fifth.
